In Fig 3 these results are represented in a different manner. The point 
D  is taken as the origin of coordinates, <s>and<\s> the "yellow" element of colour is 
represented by distances measured horizontally to the right from D, and the 
"blue" element by distances measured vertically from the horizontal line through 
D. The numerals <s>represent the<\s> indicate the different colours of the spectrum 
according to the scale shown in fig 2 and the coordinates of each point 
indicate the composition of the corresponding colour. The triangle of colours 
is reduced, in the case of dichromic vision, to a straight line "B""Y," and the 
proportions of "blue" and "yellow" in each colour are indicated by the 
ratio in which this line is cut by the line <s>through<\s> from D passing through 
the position of that colour. 

The results given above were all obtained with the light of white paper, 
placed in clear sunshine. I have obtained similar results, when the sun was hidden, by using 
the light of uniformly illuminated clouds, <s>when the sun<\s> but I do not 
consider these observations sufficiently free from <s>casu<\s> disturbing 
circumstances to be employed in calculation. It is easy, however, by means 
of such observations, to <s>test<\s> verify the most remarkable phenomena of 
colour  blindness, as for instance, that the colours from red to green appear 
to differ only in brightness, and that the brightness may be made identical 
by changing the width of the slit; that the colour near F is a neutral tint, 
and that the eye in viewing it sees a dark spot in the direction of 
the axis of vision; that the colours beyond are all blue of different 
intensities, and that any "blue" may be combined with any "yellow" 
in such proportions as to form "white." These results I have verified 
by the observations of another colourblind gentleman, who did not 
obtain sunlight for his observations; and as I have now the 
means of carrying the requisite apparatus easily, I hope to meet 
with other colour=blind observers, and to obtain their observations 
under more favourable circumstances.
